questions.text: A patient presented with regurgitation of food with foul smelling breath and intermittent dysphagia to solid foods. Diagnosis is?
A tracheostomized patient, with portex tracheostomy tube, in the ward, developed sudden complete blockage of the tube. What will be the best next step for the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube

options.label: B
options.text: Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate

questions.correct_answer: A. Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube

questions.text: A firm 2 to 3 cm mass is palpable in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast of a 52-year-old woman. There are no palpable axillary lymph nodes. A lumpectomy with axillary node dissection is performed and the breast lesion is found to have positive immunohistochemical staining for HER2/neu (ERBB2). Staining for oestrogen and progesterone receptors is negative. Which of the following additional treatment options is most appropriate, based upon these findings?

A 36-years-old woman is hospitalized for treatment of a stomach ulcer that has been getting progressively worse over several months. Radiographic studies reveal the site of involvement to be along the greater curvature, approximately 4 cm away from the pyloric sphincter. That night, the ulcer perforates, and there is considerable intra-abdominal bleeding. Surgery reveals that the ulcer has eroded through the stomach wall and has damaged the artery supply in the involved region of the stomach. Which artery was likely involved?

A patient is transported to the emergency department with a knife wound to the right Seventh intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Which of the following structures is likely to have been damaged?
A 40-years-old man complains of loss of sensation over the right scrotum and on the medial right thigh. Damage to which of the following nerves would result in such symptoms?
A 43-years-old woman is diagnosed with a condition that causes excruciating pain near her nose and mouth. The involved nerve innervates which of the following branchial arches?

A 49-years-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right upper-quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever. She also complains of pain in her right shoulder. A right upper quadrant ultrasound reveals multiple gallstones and pericholecystic fluid. Which of the following dermatomes is most likely involved in her shoulder pain?
A 23-years-old woman wearing high heel shoes inverts and sprains her ankle while running down a flight of stairs. Which of the following ligaments did she most likely injure?

A gastric biopsy is performed on a 42 years old man. As the pathologist inspects the specimen, he observes numerous, normal cuboidal-to-columnar cells with apical membrane-bound secretory granules in the gastric glands. From which area of the stomach was the biopsy specimen most likely taken?
An arteriogram is performed on a patient with atherosclerosis. Luminal narrowing of which of the following vessels would compromise blood flow through the renal arteries?
A 42-years-old man undergoes surgery for medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. After the surgery, he complains of a “noisy quality” to his voice. This condition was most likely caused by damage to the:

A prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is drawn from a 54-years-old man as part of a routine health evaluation. Which of the following embryonic strucutes gives rise to the organ being screened for carcinoma?
A 20-years-old man is stabbed immediately to the left of the body of the sternum at the fifth intercostal space. The knife most likely penetrated the:

A patient with a left adrenal mass is scheduled for surgery. The surgeon is planning to approach the suprarenal area by removing the twelfth rib. With this approach, the surgeon should take particular care to avoid damaging which of the following structures?
True about examination of the liver are all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Upper border is at the level of the 5th intercostal space in the right midclavicular line

options.label: B
options.text: Liver span is 12 – 15 cm in the right midclavicular line

options.label: C
options.text: In emphysema the dullness of the upper border of the liver extends superiorly

options.label: D
options.text: Rosenbach’s sign refers to pulsations that are transmitted to the examiner’s hand on gentle palpation of the liver

questions.correct_answer: C. In emphysema the dullness of the upper border of the liver extends superiorly

questions.text: The gallbladder of a 51-year-old female patient is characterized by the presence of multiple gallstones, consistent with the diagnosis of cholecystitis. Which of the following tests would be anticipated to be positive in this patient?
Among the following true statements are all except?

options.label: A
options.text: Discolouration around the umbilicus is known as Grey – Turner’s sign

options.label: B
options.text: Discolouration around the inguinal ligament is known as Fox’s sign

options.label: C
options.text: Discolouration around the umbilicus occurs as the fluid tracks along the lesser omentum to bare area of liver and then via the falciform ligament to the umbilicus

options.label: D
options.text: A complication of acute pancreatitis can be ischemia of the midgut

questions.correct_answer: A. Discolouration around the umbilicus is known as Grey – Turner’s sign

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with groin pain. Examination reveals that the patient has an indirect inguinal hernia. Which of the following nerves is compressed by the herniating structure in the inguinal canal to give the patient pain?

A 1-day-old female infant has a mass protruding through her umbilicus. Physical examination reveals an umbilical hernia. A CT scan reveals that part of another organ is attached to the inner surface of the hernia. What portion of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be attached to the inner surface of the umbilical hernia?

A 70-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department complaining of cramping midabdominal pain, abdominal distention, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. History reveals that the patient suffers from gallstones. Abdominal radiograph reveals air in the gallbladder and biliary tree. In which of the following sites is a gallstone most likely lodged?

A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever and a high white blood cell count. He reports having suffered a small stab wound in his back a few months ago. Because it was a shallow wound, he did not seek medical attention. The physician states that he has a retroperitoneal infection. Which of the following structures is most likely to be affected?

25-year-old woman in the 8th month of pregnancy went to the outpatient clinic for her prenatal checkup. Ultrasound examination of the fetus showed part of the small bowel herniating into the amniotic cavity due to failure of fusion of the lateral folds in the abdominal region. Which condition is this?

A 35-year-old man is in surgery for a ruptured appendix. A midline incision was made for greater access to the peritoneal cavity. The surgeon noted a 2-inch long finger-like pouch on the anterior border of the ileum about 2 feet away from the ileocecal junction. This is a remnant of which developmental structure?

A 47-year-old man is undergoing surgical repair of a perforated duodenal ulcer. During the procedure the gastroduodenal artery is ligated. A branch of which artery will continue to supply blood to the duodenum and head of pancreas in this patient?

A 50-year-old woman with a long history of heartburn (self-treated with various over-the-counter medications) develops severe epigastric pain and is urgently admitted to the hospital. A gastroscopic examination reveals a small, perforated ulceration in the posterior wall of the stomach body. At surgery, with the patient in the supine position, 150 mL of blood-tinged, frothy grey liquid is aspirated from the peritoneal cavity. Where in the peritoneal cavity would liquid most likely first collect when the patient is supine?

A 43-year-old female accountant complains of severe epigastric pain and is admitted to the hospital. A gastroscopic examination reveals a small, perforated ulceration in the posterior wall of the greater curvature of her stomach. An upright chest radiograph reveals a small amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity. Where is the air most likely located?

A 60-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals guarding and rigidity in the abdominal wall. An abdominal CT scan shows a thrombus in an intestinal artery supplying the ileum. Which of the following layers of peritoneum will have to be entered by the surgeon to access the affected vessel?

options.label: A
options.text: Parietal peritoneum and the greater omentum

options.label: C
options.text: Lesser omentum and the gastrosplenic ligament

questions.correct_answer: D. Parietal peritoneum and the mesentery

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of persistent severe right upper quadrant pain for the past 2 hours. During that period of time he felt nauseated, was sweating profusely, and also experienced pain in the posterior aspect of his right shoulder and upper back. The pain began shortly after a lunch consisting of “fast food.” Ultrasound examination reveals multiple stones in an inflamed gallbladder with a normal bile duct. Which of the following spinal nerve segments are involved in the shoulder pain, associated with cholecystitis?

During a cholecystectomy on a 64-year-old woman, the right hepatic artery was accidentally injured. In addition to bleeding profusely, the lacerated artery was hidden from view by overlying connective tissue and fat plus pooling blood. Which of the following procedures would most likely be performed by the surgeon to slow, or perhaps arrest, the blood loss?

options.label: D
options.text: Placement of a vascular clamp on the portahepatis

questions.text: All are examples of herniorrhaphy except?

A 53-year-old male has typical symptoms of GERD refractory to medical management and is referred to your clinic to discuss surgical options. He has previously had a distal pancreatectomy/splenectomy from a gunshot wound and three subsequent laparotomies for adhesive bowel obstruction. What surgical option allows for satisfactory control of reflux while avoiding the abdomen?

A 55-year-old man is evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. A barium oesophagogram shows a 3-cm smooth filling defect in the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is true of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Cystic transformation or central necrosis is often associated with these lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Patients often have hematemesis or chronic anemia because of ulceration

options.label: C
options.text: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) will show a hypoechoic mass in the submucosa.

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic biopsy should be performed to rule out malignancy

questions.correct_answer: C. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) will show a hypoechoic mass in the submucosa.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of chest pain and dysphagia. Manometric studies show simultaneous multipeaked contractions of 140 mmHg, lasting 4 to 5 s, and normal LES relaxation. Which of the following is true of her disease?

options.label: B
options.text: It can be caused by infection with Trypanosoma cruzi

options.label: C
options.text: It is the result of fibrous replacement of the esophageal smooth muscle.

options.label: D
options.text: It is also known as “vigorous” achalasia

questions.correct_answer: A. Esophagography will show a “corkscrew esophagus.”

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has GERD and episodic dysphagia. An upper gastrointestinal contrast-enhanced study shows a type I hiatal hernia and thin band-like narrowing of the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is true of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral dilation is the treatment of choice.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the result of hypertrophy of the circular muscle layer.

options.label: D
options.text: There is squamous mucosa above and below the narrowing.

questions.correct_answer: A. Oral dilation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Dysphagia lusoria is most likely associated with:

A 65-year-old obese man undergoes emergent aortic aneurysm repair. He requires large-volume resuscitation due to the long operative time. After surgery, he develops rhabdomyolysis, oliguria, and volume overload. His abdomen becomes distended. An abdominal x-ray reveals a gas pattern consistent with ileus; there is mildly dilated small bowel with a paucity of gas in the colon. Although his vitals are stable, tenderness is illicited on examination of abdomen. Bladder pressure is measured to be 22 mmHg. What is the appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Heavily sedate and paralyze the patient. Repeat bladder pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Heavily sedate the patient. Repeat the bladder pressure the following day

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a decompressive laparotomy with a temporary abdominal closure

questions.correct_answer: A. Heavily sedate and paralyze the patient. Repeat bladder pressure.

questions.text: A 40 years old man presented with a painless abdominal lump, located in the umbilical region, which became less prominent on raising the legs, with positive Tillaux’s sign. CT scan was done which is shown below. The contents of the lump were aspirated under USG guidance. The aspirate was milky in appearance. False about the management of this condition is?

options.label: B
options.text: Partial excision with marsupialisation can be done for large cysts or those lying at the root

options.label: C
options.text: Sclerotherapy can be done using 10% glucose solution

options.label: D
options.text: A segment of bowel resection is almost always required

questions.correct_answer: D. A segment of bowel resection is almost always required

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and fullness. A CT scan was done which was suggestive of a retroperitoneal mass and a diagnosis of retroperioneal sarcoma was made. What is false regarding the condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Chemotherapy + radiotherapy is the treatment of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Most common vessels to be involved which preclude surgery are proximal SMA and renal arteries

questions.correct_answer: C. Chemotherapy + radiotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: 20-year-old female presents with dysphagia to liquids and regurgitation. A barium swallow was done. What is false regarding the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The disorders of this group are classified under the Chicago classification

options.label: B
options.text: T. cruzi infection can cause similar symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: Peroral endoscopic myotomy is an available treatment modality

questions.text: A 47-year-old alcoholic man is having epigastric and midabdominal pain, which began shortly after he ate a large meal. The pain reached maximum intensity in about 12 hours and is now constant, severe, and radiating to his back. He vomited early on and has continued to retch even after his stomach was empty. Although he has discomfort when his upper abdomen is palpated, the physical exam is less impressive than the severity of his pain would suggest. He is afebrile. Serum lipase is very elevated, and hematocrit is 54. The most likely diagnosis is:
Helicobacter pylori infection primarily mediates duodenal ulcer pathogenesis via

options.label: A
options.text: Antral alkalinization leading to inhibition of somatostatin release

options.label: D
options.text: Upregulation of parietal cell acid production

questions.correct_answer: A. Antral alkalinization leading to inhibition of somatostatin release

questions.text: A 55-year-old executive who is seen because of severe epigastric pain is found on esophagogastroduodenoscopy to have a large ulcer in the duodenal bulb and tests positive for H. pylori. He is treated for H. pylori and instructed to quit smoking, but his symptoms persist and he is referred to you for further management. At this time, it would be most appropriate to recommend

options.label: A
options.text: NSAID cessation and urea breath test

questions.correct_answer: A. NSAID cessation and urea breath test

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with malena and anemia requiring recurrent blood transfusion underwent upper G.I. endoscopy. What is the best treatment for this patient?
A middle-aged patient who presented with epigastric pain, weight loss, diarrhea, and hypoproteinemia underwent upper G.I. endoscopy. What is false regarding the management of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: H. pylori eradication therapy can resolve symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: Total gastrectomy may be indicated for bleeding

questions.correct_answer: C. It does not regress spontaneously

questions.text: A patient presents with severe epigastric pain, retching without vomiting. Attempt to pass a nasogastric tube failed. What is false regarding this condtion?

options.label: A
options.text: Organoaxial rotation is less common than mesenteroaxial

options.label: B
options.text: Contrast study is superior than endoscopy

questions.correct_answer: A. Organoaxial rotation is less common than mesenteroaxial

questions.text: Which of the following bariatric procedures is primarily intended to induce weight loss through malabsorption of ingested nutrients?
False about anatomy of liver?

options.label: A
options.text: Cantlie’s line passes from the gall bladder fossa to the IVC

options.label: B
options.text: Middle hepatic vein passes through the Cantlie’s line

options.label: C
options.text: Caudate lobe has independent venous drainage

questions.correct_answer: D. Quadrate lobe is segment I

questions.text: All of the following are used for scoring Child – Turcotte – Pugh classification of hepatocellular function in cirrhosis except?

A 42-year-old female underwent an uneventful laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Two weeks later she presents to the emergency department with vague abdominal pain. Her vitals are normal and stable. Total bilirubin is 1.1 mg/dL. CT scan demonstrates a large bilioma. Which of the following is the best choice for definitive intervention?
questions.correct_answer: B. ERCP with biliary stent placement

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents for evaluation of yellow skin. Review of systems is significant for loose-fitting clothes, fatigue, and night sweats. Laboratory evaluation is remarkable for elevated total bilirubin. CT scan reveals a pancreatic mass. Which of the following is least likely to contribute to this condition?
A 50-year-old male has an incidentally discovered 8-cm nonparasitic splenic cyst. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Most are symptomatic and present with left upper quadrant tenderness.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient should undergo percutaneous aspiration.

questions.text: A 22 years old female patient presents with pain abdomen, jaundice. MRCP was done which is shown below. What is the management?

options.label: B
options.text: Cyst resection and primary re-anastomosis of the common bile duct.

options.label: C
options.text: Resection of the common bile duct, cholecystectomy, and hepatico-jejunostomy

options.label: D
options.text: Resection of the cyst and choledocho-duodenostomy

questions.correct_answer: C. Resection of the common bile duct, cholecystectomy, and hepatico-jejunostomy

questions.text: According to the Bismuth-Corlette classification system, perihilar cholangiocarcinomas extending into the right secondary intrahepatic ducts are classified as?
What is the best initial management for an intraoperatively identified minor lateral injury to the common bile duct?

options.label: A
options.text: Placement of a -tube through the site of injury in the duct.

options.label: B
options.text: Primary oversew of the injury intraoperatively.

options.label: C
options.text: Resection of the injured portion of the duct with end- to- end anastomosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Intraoperative placement of endoscopic biliary stent

questions.correct_answer: A. Placement of a -tube through the site of injury in the duct.

questions.text: According to Ranson criteria a 67-year-old female patient suspected of acute pancreatitis presenting to the ER with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, a serum aspartate transaminase (AST) >250 U/dL, a white blood cell (WBC) >16,000/mm3, and a blood glucose >200 mg/dL would receive a disease classification of
In the resection of a stenotic area of intestine in a patient with Crohn’s disease, the best approach is

options.label: A
options.text: A resection margin of 2 cm from gross disease.

options.label: B
options.text: A resection margin of 12 cm from gross disease.

options.label: C
options.text: A resection margin 2 cm from microscopic disease on frozen section.

options.label: D
options.text: A resection margin 12 cm from microscopic disease on frozen section

questions.correct_answer: A. A resection margin of 2 cm from gross disease.

questions.text: The failure of an enterocutaneous fistula to heal on a regimen of total parenteral nutrition and antisecretory therapy may be due to which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: A foreign body in the fistula tract.

options.label: C
options.text: Downstream obstruction of the fistulized segment of intestine.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with medically refractory ulcerative colitis undergoes a total colectomy with J-pouch creation. What are some of the late complications of ileal pouch anal reconstruction?

options.label: A
options.text: More than eight bowel movements per day

questions.text: What structures are most likely to be sites of extracolonic disease in inflammatory bowel disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Liver, biliary tree, joints, skin, eyes

questions.correct_answer: A. Liver, biliary tree, joints, skin, eyes

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe pain on defecation that began 2 months ago. On rectal examination, a fissure is found. What would indicate that this fissure is due to Crohn disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Deep and broad ulcer located in the lateral position.

options.label: B
options.text: Shallow and broad ulcer located in the anterior position.

options.label: C
options.text: Deep and narrow ulcer located in the posterior midline position.

options.label: D
options.text: Shallow and narrow ulcer located in the lateral position

questions.correct_answer: A. Deep and broad ulcer located in the lateral position.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the ED with fever, abdominal pain, and bloody stools or the past 2 days. On CT scan he is found to have diverticulitis with scant free air and a small fluid collection associated with the sigmoid colon. What is the etiology of diverticulosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of dietary fiber causes smaller stools volume requiring higher intraluminal pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic contraction causes muscular hypertrophy and causes colon to act as segments rather than a continuous tube.

options.label: C
options.text: The mucosa and muscularis mucosa herniate through the colon wall.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the ED with a 2-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain and is found to be febrile to 38.6°C. Her white blood cell (WBC) count is 15,000. On CT scan she is found to have colonic inflammation with an associated pericolic abscess. What is her Hinchey stage?

58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of the sensation of urinating air. He has a history of diverticulitis, with his last episode requiring hospitalization being 6 months ago. What are the most common fistulas that develop in complicated diverticulitis?
A 63-year-old man undergoes a screening colonoscopy and is found to have a polyp in his sigmoid colon. Which type of polyp is most associated with malignancy?

A 67-year-old man presents to the ED with a 2-month history of nausea, emesis, 20-lb weight loss, and worsening diarrhea until 4 days ago, when he stopped passing flatus and having bowel movements. A CT scan shows a large obstructing right colon mass that may be involving the omentum with two liver lesions. What should be resected in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Right hemicolectomy, involved omentum, and as many of the peritoneal masses you can.

options.label: B
options.text: Right hemicolectomy with arterial supply and as many nodes as you can.

options.label: C
options.text: Right hemicolectomy with arterial supply, at least 12 nodes, the involved omentum, and resectable liver masses.

options.label: D
options.text: Don’t do a colon resection as the patient has distant metastases and should be diverted for palliation

questions.correct_answer: C. Right hemicolectomy with arterial supply, at least 12 nodes, the involved omentum, and resectable liver masses.

questions.text: While reviewing pathology of a recent laparoscopic appendectomy, in addition to acute appendicitis, the patient had a 1.5-cm carcinoid tumor located at the base of the appendix. The patient is otherwise healthy and recovering well from surgery. What would you recommend?
Which of the following physical signs is being demonstrated?

A 19 year – old – male patient presents with pain abdomen in the right lower quadrant, with tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa on palpation. He has a history of anorexia and migration of pain. His total leukocyte count is 16,000/µl with 90% neutrophils. He has no history of nausea/ vomiting or fever. What is his total Alvarado score?
A 45-year-old woman presents with RLQ pain. A CT scan is performed. What finding on CT scan is most suggestive of appendiceal lymphoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Appendiceal diameter >2.5 cm or surrounding soft tissue thickening

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of contrast filling the appendix

options.label: C
options.text: 1-cm mass at the base of the appendix

questions.correct_answer: A. Appendiceal diameter >2.5 cm or surrounding soft tissue thickening

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with redness, pain, and fluctuance in the intergluteal cleft, about 4 cm posterior to the anus. There is considerable hair adjacent to the lesion. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Incision and drainage in the intergluteal cleft

options.label: B
options.text: Incision and drainage lateral to the intergluteal cleft

options.label: C
options.text: En bloc excision of the sinus tract with flap reconstruction

questions.correct_answer: B. Incision and drainage lateral to the intergluteal cleft

questions.text: Twelve hours after hemorrhoidal banding, a 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting rectal and abdominal pain and an inability to urinate. His temperature is 102°F and heartrate is 110 beats per minute. Management consists of

options.label: C
options.text: Broad-spectrum antibiotics and rectal examination with the patient under anesthesia

questions.correct_answer: C. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and rectal examination with the patient under anesthesia

questions.text: The chemotherapeutic agents commonly used and favored for anal canal carcinoma are:
A patient presents pain during defecation with on and off bleeding. Which of the following medical therapies results in the greatest healing rates for this condition?
An 80-year-old woman presents with rectal prolapse. She has a history of chronic constipation.Colonoscopy findings are negative. Treatment would be best achieved via:

options.label: A
options.text: Fixation of the rectum with prosthetic sling (Ripstein repair)

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with unresectable cholangiocarcinoma undergoing palliative therapy presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and cough for 1 day. Temperature was 101.7°F, pulse 93 beats/min, blood pressure 112/65 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination shows a soft and non distended abdomen with tenderness in the right upper quadrant and hepatomegaly. Lab results include a white blood cell count of 14,000/mm3 and alkaline phosphatase level of 215 IU/L. Chest x-ray shows an elevated right hemi-diaphragm and right lower lobe atelectasis. Ultrasound is performed showing a round hypoechoic lesion within the liver, with well-defined borders and several internal echoes, mildly dilated intrahepatic bile ducts, and no cholelithiasis or pericholecystic fluid. In addition to further imaging, what is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Percutaneous drainage and intravenous (IV) antibiotics

questions.text: A 30-year-old man visiting from Mexico comes to the emergency department with a history of 2 weeks of right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, fevers, chills, and diarrhea. He is febrile to 102.9°F. His heart rate and blood pressure are 120 beats/min and 100/75 mmHg, respectively. Laboratory results include a white blood cell count of 16,000/mm3, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 50 IU/L, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 93 IU/L. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a 4 × 7-cm round, hypoechoic, nonhomogeneous lesion abutting the liver capsule without rim echoes. Subsequent CT also demonstrates a non–rim-enhancing hypoechoic lesion with a smaller adjacent lesion measuring 2 × 2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

options.label: D
options.text: Serologic testing for Entamoeba histolytica and oral metronidazole

questions.correct_answer: D. Serologic testing for Entamoeba histolytica and oral metronidazole

questions.text: A 28-year-old asymptomatic white woman is incidentally found to have a 3.5-cm hypervascular lesion with a central scar in the right lobe of her liver. On delayed images, there is increased uptake of contrast material in the scar in comparison with the surrounding liver parenchyma. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Liver enzyme and alpha-fetoprotein levels are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient ?

Right upper quadrant abdominal pain develops in a 25-year old woman taking oral contraceptives. CT demonstrates a hypodense, 6-cm mass in the right lobe of the liver. A 99mTc-labelled scan reveals a defect in the area of the mass. Angiography reveals a hypervascular tumor with a peripheral blood supply. Which of the following is the appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinuation of oral contraceptives and observation with serial CT

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with recurrent breast cancer undergoes CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis for metastatic workup. She is found to have a 7-cm liver mass. Follow up triple phase CT shows a hypervascular lesion with peripheral to central enhancement. It is thought to be a hemangioma. She denies abdominal pain or any episodes of jaundice. What would be a reasonable indication for operative intervention?

options.label: A
options.text: Pain, shortness of breath, early satiety

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with hypertension presents to her primary care physician (PCP) with right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. There is a palpable soft mass along her liver edge. Workup is negative for viral hepatitis, and liver ultrasound shows a 4-cm cystic structure that is extrahepatic and separate from the gallbladder. ERCP is performed and demonstrates a biliary diverticulum obstructing the common bile duct. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 75-year-old man with hepatitis C cirrhosis presents for an annual checkup. He denies any new complaints, including jaundice, abdominal pain, ascites, gastrointestinal bleeding or encephalopathy. Temperature is 99.1°F, pulse 85 beats/ min, blood pressure 109/78 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. What studies should be ordered?

A 69-year-old woman with Child’s C cirrhosis has an elevated AFP and a new liver mass on ultrasound. Triple phase contrast CT confirms a 3.5 ×4 cm2 mass with arterial enhancement and venous washout. She is otherwise healthy with no cardiopulmonary disease. What is the next most appropriate step in workup and treatment?

A 55-year-old woman with a history of colorectal cancer 10 years ago, treated with right hemicolectomy and chemotherapy and with no evidence of disease since then, presents with vague abdominal pain. Temperature is 98.7°F, pulse 67 beats/min, blood pressure 132/78 mmHg, and saturation 99% on room air. Labs are remarkable for AST 67 IU/L, ALT 83 IU/L, and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)-27 ng/mL. Triple-phase contrast CT shows a new peripheral liver mass that slightly enhances on arterial phase. She has hypertension that is well controlled with medications. What is the most likely diagnosis and most appropriate management of her liver lesion?

A 43-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis has had increasing abdominal distension over the last month. His vital signs are stable, and he is afebrile. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a fluid wave. The initial management of the patient’s ascites should include all of the following except:

A 43-year-old woman with primary biliary cirrhosis complicated by massive ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, and multiple episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleed requiring endoscopic management presents with hematemesis. Temperature is 98.7°F, pulse 109 beats/min, blood pressure 103/77 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and saturation 97% on 2 L of nasal cannula oxygen. After acute resuscitation with intravenous fluids and blood products, EGD is performed showing multiple bleeding esophageal varices, which undergo endoscopic band ligation. When the patient is stabilized, TIPS is considered. Further workup including chest radiography shows a large right pleural effusion. What is the most important relative contraindication for portovenous shunting?

A 57-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain and a large umbilical hernia. Temperature is 97.8°F, pulse 78 beats/min, blood pressure 105/63 mmHg, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. Exam shows a large, dull to percussion abdomen with flank fullness, a fluid shift, and a reducible umbilical hernia. What is the most appropriate management?

A 63-y/o female undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. The pathology report states that there is a foci of carcinoma which invades, but does not penetrate through the lamina propria. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Laparoscopic resection of the gallbladder fossa

options.label: B
options.text: Open extended cholecystectomy including segment 4b and 5 liver resection as well as removal of porta hepatis lymph nodes

options.label: D
options.text: CBD excision to achieve negative margins with Roux-en- Y hepaticojejunostomy reconstruction

questions.text: A 40-y/o man is evaluated for fluctuating jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. Liver enzyme levels demonstrate cholestasis. Ultrasound imaging does not show gallstones or bile duct dilation. What diagnostic test should be obtained next?
questions.correct_answer: A. Measurement of serum anti-mitochondrial antibodies

questions.text: A 22-y/o female presents to the emergency room with RUQ pain and jaundice. Ultrasound shows a normal appearing gallbladder without stones, but a diffusely dilated CBD. Follow-up ERCP confirms a diffusely dilated fusiform extrahepatic bile duct without filling defects, and normal-appearing intrahepatic biliary anatomy. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation, since there is no evidence of choledocholithiasis

options.label: D
options.text: Complete surgical excision of the dilated bile duct segment and reconstruction with a hepaticojejunostomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Complete surgical excision of the dilated bile duct segment and reconstruction with a hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 73-y/o female presents with acute onset of abdominal distention, pain, nausea and vomiting. She has no previous surgeries. She has no abdominal or inguinal hernias on examination. Abdominal x-ray shows dilated small bowel with air-fluid levels and pneumobilia. The obstruction is most likely at which site?

A 38-y/o male presents to the emergency department with fevers and RUQ pain. His temperature is 39°C, he is tachycardic to 110/min and the remainder of his vitals are normal. On abdominal examination, he has a positive Murphy’s sign. Laboratory values are significant for a WBC count of 15,000/mm3 and a total bilirubin of 5.5 mg/dL. Ultrasound shows a thickened gallbladder wall, stones, pericholecystic fluid, and a CBD diameter of 8 mm. What is the most appropriate initial management?

options.label: A
options.text: IV fluids resuscitation and antibiotics, and biliary drainage if no response to treatment in 24 h

options.label: B
options.text: IV fluids resuscitation, antibiotics, and urgent biliary drainage

questions.correct_answer: B. IV fluids resuscitation, antibiotics, and urgent biliary drainage

questions.text: Two weeks following hepaticojejunostomy for the treatment of a benign bile duct stricture, a patient has a serum bilirubin level of 6 mg/dL. The patient was jaundiced for 4 weeks before the operation and had a preoperative serum bilirubin level of 12 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this current serum bilirubin level?

options.label: D
options.text: Normal expected decline after relief of any obstructive Jaundice

questions.text: A 35-y/o female presents with choledocholithiasis. A laparoscopic cholecystectomy with biliary clearance is recommended. Which of the following is FALSE regarding laparoscopic CBD exploration (LCBDE) versus preoperative ERCP followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy?

options.label: B
options.text: Hospital stay is shorter for the LCBDE group.

options.label: C
options.text: Cost is greater for the ERCP followed by the LCBDE group.

options.label: D
options.text: There are fewer retained stones after the laparoscopic common bile duct exploration (LCBDE) group.

questions.correct_answer: D. There are fewer retained stones after the laparoscopic common bile duct exploration (LCBDE) group.

questions.text: A 71-y/o female presents to your office for a persistent high-output biliary fistula 3 weeks after you performed a subtotal fenestrating cholecystectomy with subhepatic Jackson Pratt (JP) drain placement for acute cholecystitis. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Observation as a persistent fistula is expected after a subtotal fenestrating cholecystectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Make her nil per oral and start TPN

questions.text: A 26-y/o female who is 10 weeks pregnant presents to your office with symptomatic cholelithiasis. She has had two recent trips to the emergency room for significant pain. Her ultrasound from her most recent visit demonstrates a wall of 3 mm, no pericholecystic fluid, an impacted stone in the neck of the gallbladder, and a CBD of 4 mm. On examination, she has mild RUQ pain but no Murphy’s sign. The most appropriate management is:

A 46-y/o male presents with 2 days of RUQ pain. His labs are significant for a WBC count of 15,000/mm3. His ultrasound notes numerous gallstones with wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid. On examination, his temperature is 99.5°F, and he has a positive Murphy’s sign. What is the best management for this individual?

A 99mTc-iminodiacetic acid scan in a fasting patient demonstrates the following: normal liver activity, no gallbladder visualization at 60 min, intestinal activity present at 60 min, and gallbladder visualization at 120 min. These findings are most consistent with which of the following situations?

A 58-year-old woman with jaundice underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) as a part of her diagnostic workup. On the basis of this radiograph, what is the most likely diagnosis?

68-year-old man presents with painless jaundice. He has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and alcohol abuse. He has a 40-pack-year tobacco history. He has been hospitalized for pancreatitis three times in the past. Computed tomography (CT) scan shows a 2-cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and biopsy confirm pancreatic adenocarcinoma. He asks you what most likely would have contributed to this diagnosis of ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

A 45-year-old woman was seen at an outside hospital with abdominal pain, and a CT scan was performed showing a pancreatic cyst. The interventional radiologist drained the cyst during that admission, and the patient was sent home. She presents now to your hospital, and a CT scan again shows a septated, 10-cm cystic mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following statements constitutes appropriate advice?

options.label: A
options.text: The lesion is benign and requires no intervention

options.label: B
options.text: The lesion is malignant and probably incurable

questions.text: A jaundiced, otherwise healthy patient is noted to have a 3-cm mass in the head of the pancreas on CT. EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration shows cancer. The mass abuts the portal vein, but there is no clear evidence of vessel involvement or metastatic disease. You proceed to the operating room. Intraoperatively, you are concerned about the respectability of the tumor. In which of the following situations is resection contraindicated?

options.label: A
options.text: 270º abutment of the superior mesenteric artery

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor located in the neck of the pancreas

options.label: C
options.text: Inability to verify malignancy histologically before resection

options.label: D
options.text: 90º abutment of the superior mesenteric vein

questions.correct_answer: A. 270º abutment of the superior mesenteric artery

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the emergency department (ED) with nausea, vomiting, and pain in the epigastrium and right upper quadrant (RUQ). She is afebrile and hemodynamically stable. Her WBC is 10,000 cells per MCL without a left shift, and total bilirubin is 2.5 mg/dL. The common bile duct was not identified on subsequent ultrasound due to overlying bowel gas. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) confirms a gallstone in the common bile duct with proximal dilation. Incidentally, she is found to have pancreatic divisum. What is the etiology of this?

options.label: A
options.text: Aplasia of the dorsal pancreatic anlage

options.label: B
options.text: Aplasia of the ventral pancreatic anlage

options.label: C
options.text: Incomplete rotation of the ventral pancreatic anlage

options.label: D
options.text: Failed fusion of the ventral and dorsal pancreatic ducts

questions.correct_answer: D. Failed fusion of the ventral and dorsal pancreatic ducts

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with recurrent alcoholic pancreatitis presents to the ED with 3 days of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Further questioning elicits symptoms including rigors and subjective fevers. His temperature is 102.5°F, WBC is 23,000 cells per MCL, heart rate is 105 beats/ min, and blood pressure is 118/64 mmHg. CT scan is obtained, which shows a hypoenhancing pancreas with necrosis and air bubbles, a small pseudocyst, and a second peripancreatic fluid collection. Which of the following complications of acute pancreatitis is associated with the highest mortality rate?

A 54-year-old male presents to the ED with RUQ pain and epigastric pain and associated emesis. Lab results are significant for a total bilirubin of 1.9 g/dL, WBC of 11,500 cells per MCL, and lipase level of 300 U/L, and AST/ALT are mildly elevated. An USG is performed showing a duct of 6 mm and numerous mobile stones in the gallbladder. Acute gallstone pancreatitis is diagnosed. Which of the following is considered standard treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Urgent (within 24 h) cholecystectomy and common bile duct exploration

options.label: B
options.text: Urgent ERCP and subsequent laparoscopic cholecystectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Initial supportive therapy with cholecystectomy performed during the same admission

options.label: D
options.text: Initial supportive therapy with cholecystectomy performed in 6 to 8 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Initial supportive therapy with cholecystectomy performed during the same admission

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to his primary care physician (PCP) with abdominal pain in the epigastrium and associated nausea. No other significant findings are observed. The patient denies any alcohol or tobacco use. The PCP sends him to the ED for a CT scan, which shows a lesion in the pancreas. The patient subsequently undergoes an EUS/ ERCP, which shows mucin at the ampulla. MRI and biopsy results confirm a main duct–type IPMN. Which of the following features of IPMN of the pancreas is associated with the lowest risk for cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Branch duct type with mural nodularity

options.label: B
options.text: Branch duct type smaller than 3 cm

options.label: C
options.text: Main duct type with diffuse dilation to greater than 10 mm

options.label: D
options.text: Main duct type with segmental dilation

questions.correct_answer: B. Branch duct type smaller than 3 cm

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to your office with a new onset of vague epigastric pain and jaundice. She denies any weight loss. To her knowledge, this has not happened before. Lab results are significant for a WBC of 12,000 cells per MCL and a total bilirubin of 2.0 mg/dL. You send her to the emergency room for a CT scan. Subsequent ERCP showed areas of irregular narrowing throughout the intrapancreatic common bile duct. No masses are identified on EUS. What is the initial treatment of choice for this patient?

A 62-year-old male with an extensive history of recurrent alcoholic pancreatitis presents to the ED with progressively worsening shortness of breath. His last attack of pancreatitis was 9 months ago. At that time, a new fluid collection around the pancreas and extensive calcifications throughout the pancreas were noted. On examination, he is saturating 94% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs reveals absent breath sounds two-thirds of the way up his left lung fields. The right chest has breath sounds throughout. X-ray shows a large left pleural effusion. WBC count is 6,000 cells per MCL, and the patient is afebrile and hemodynamically stable. He has vague abdominal pain and had one episode of emesis in the ED. CT chest/abdomen displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old male presents to the ED with complaints of epigastric abdominal fullness and occasional pain over the past 8 months with associated nausea. He confirms a long-standing history of acute on chronic pancreatitis secondary to alcohol abuse. A CT scan from a prior admission 10 months ago showed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. In the ED, he has one episode of blood-tinged emesis. He remains hemodynamically stable, with a hemoglobin of 10 g/ dL. A CT scan is obtained. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Interventional radiology (IR) angiography and embolization

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman complains to her physician of symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. On examination she has a palpable nodule, but no evidence of exophthalmos. She does have pretibial myxedema. Her laboratory workup reveals a suppressed thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level with elevated free T3. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

A 72-year-old woman with Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is evaluated for a rapidly enlarging neck mass. The patient takes levothyroxine replacement. Despite no change in her medication dosage, she has been experiencing fevers, night sweats, and weight loss. Ultrasound reveals a 4-cm left thyroid mass with a pseudocystic pattern. FNA is nondiagnostic. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

The patient comes to the emergency department 6 months after surgery complaining of a 2-day history of epigastric abdominal pain and emesis without relief. In the emergency department her temperature is 98.9°F with a pulse of 99 beats/min and blood pressure of 140/70 mmHg. Her abdomen is soft with mild distention, normal bowel sounds, and vague discomfort on palpation. CT of the abdomen reveals the passage of oral contrast to the colon without evidence of free fluid, extravasation of contrast, or pneumoperitoneum. The excluded stomach and the entire length of the biliopancreatic limb are dilated. The biliopancreatic limb appears to be in its normal location. The patient will most likely require which one of the following?

A 35-year-old man with long-standing morbid obesity is evaluated for bariatric surgery. He is 5 ft 8 inch tall, weighs 210 kg with a BMI of 72.2 kg/m2, and has limited mobility requiring the assistance of a walker. His medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and GERD. Which of the following is true when discussing BPD as an option for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins is rare

options.label: B
options.text: Protein malnutrition is the most significant long-term complication seen after BPD.

options.label: D
options.text: Long-term weight-loss results are not as good as with gastric bypass.

questions.correct_answer: B. Protein malnutrition is the most significant long-term complication seen after BPD.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department 8 h after balloon dilation of her esophagus with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. She was found to be febrile, tachycardic, and normotensive. Esophagography showed “bird’s beak” narrowing and a leak at the distal end of the esophagus with contrast material in the left side of the chest. After fluid resuscitation and antibiotics, which of the following is the most appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopic evaluation of the injury and stenting

options.label: C
options.text: Left thoracotomy, primary repair, myotomy, and drain placement

options.label: D
options.text: Laparotomy, primary repair, and gastrostomy tube Placement

questions.correct_answer: C. Left thoracotomy, primary repair, myotomy, and drain placement

questions.text: A 75-year-old white man with a history of alcohol abuse, 40-pack-per year tobacco use, and long-standing GERD controlled by antacids is evaluated for dysphagia and weight loss. Esophagography shows an apple core lesion at the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is true regarding further workup?

options.label: A
options.text: Endoscopic biopsy should be avoided because of the risk for perforation.

options.label: B
options.text: CT is excellent for tumor staging.

options.label: C
options.text: Positron emission tomography (PET) is an excellent tool for staging and can be used as a single diagnostic modality.

options.label: D
options.text: EUS is more sensitive than CT for evaluating the celiac lymph nodes.

questions.correct_answer: D. EUS is more sensitive than CT for evaluating the celiac lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old thin woman with a history of surgical correction of her scoliosis is evaluated for symptoms of postprandial epigastric pain, fullness, nausea, and vomiting. Her physical examination is unremarkable except for her thin physique/stature. Barium upper GI series showed a dilated duodenum and stomach with minimal flow of barium into the jejunum. Which of the following is the operative management of choice for this patient’s condition?

A 56-year-old woman had a right hemicolectomy for villous adenoma of the cecum. Five days after surgery her surgical wound becomes red and tender. She underwent pelvic radiation therapy 5 years ago for cervical cancer. The surgeon opens her wound with immediate drainage of purulent fluid. The drainage persists as a continuous brown liquid discharge over the next day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Anastomotic leakage with an enterocutaneous fistula

questions.correct_answer: C. Anastomotic leakage with an enterocutaneous fistula

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is suspected of having acute appendicitis. On physical examination his abdomen is soft and nondistended. He does not have pain with coughing or reproduction of tenderness in the right lower quadrant when palpated in the left lower quadrant. He experiences abdominal pain during extension of the right thigh while lying on his left side. He does not have pain with passive rotation of his right hip in a flexed position. Where do you suspect the location of the tip of his appendix to be?

options.label: A
options.text: Displaced to the right upper quadrant

options.label: B
options.text: Extraperitoneal and lying anterior to the cecum

questions.correct_answer: D. Retrocecal over the psoas muscle

questions.text: A 30-year-old, 28-week pregnant female presents to the emergency department with a 24-h history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The white blood cell (WBC) count is 18,000. An ultrasound was done showing a normal gallbladder and viable fetus. The appendix was not visualized. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Treat with antibiotics in an attempt to avoid an operation.

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and proceed with an appendectomy if positive

questions.correct_answer: D. Obtain a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and proceed with an appendectomy if positive

questions.text: A 35-year-old male underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. On final pathology, he was found to have a 1.4-cm carcinoid tumor in the mid-appendix with direct extension to the mesoappendix, negative margins, and no lymphovascular invasion. What is the best treatment plan?

A screening colonoscopy identifies a broad sessile villous appearing lesion of the rectum beginning 4 cm above the anal verge and extending 5 cm proximally. Biopsies show a villous adenoma with dysplasia. Endorectal ultrasound (EUS) shows that the muscularis propria is not involved. No suspicious lymph nodes are seen. Which of the following approaches is the most appropriate for the management of this patient?

A 21-year-old woman is noted to have persistent bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever. Stool studies are negative for infectious diarrhea. Colonoscopy reveals friable mucosa in a continuous manner from the rectum to the sigmoid colon. No granulomas are found on biopsy. Which of the following statements is true regarding the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Pseudopolyps and cobblestoning are common colonoscopic findings.

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery is curative for this diagnosis

options.label: C
options.text: Rectal sparing is commonly seen on colonoscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Perianal fistulas are commonly found on rectal Examination

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgery is curative for this diagnosis
